item.title: El Chapo, Mexican Drug Kingpin, Is Extradited to U.S.
item.media:description: Joaquín Guzmán Loera, known as El Chapo, was escorted off a plane at Long Island MacArthur Airport in Islip, N.Y., on Thursday. The decision to extradite Mr. Guzmán was an about-face for the Mexican government, which once claimed that he would serve his long sentence in Mexico first.
item.media:credit: U.S. law enforcement, via Associated Press
item.description: In an about-face for the Mexican government, Joaquín Guzmán Loera, known as El Chapo, was turned over to American officials on Thursday night.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED

item.title: U.S. Prosecutors Outline Case Against Mexican Drug Lord ‘El Chapo’
item.media:description: Joaquín Guzmán Loera arrived at MacArthur Airport on Long Island on Thursday night.
item.description: A detention memo contends that Joaquín Guzmán Loera transformed the narcotics trade, deploying savagery and the corrupting force of unchecked profits.
item.dc:creator: ALAN FEUER and WILLIAM K. RASHBAUM

item.title: Troops Enter Gambia as New President Is Sworn In
item.media:description: Adama Barrow, the newly elected president of Gambia, after being sworn in on Thursday in a ceremony at an embassy in neighboring Senegal.
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.description: Yahya Jammeh, Gambia’s leader for 22 years, is refusing to make way for the newly elected president, Adama Barrow, who has yet to enter his own country as president.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY and JAIME YAYA BARRY

item.title: Julian Assange Repeats Offer of Extradition to U.S.
item.media:description: Julian Assange on the balcony of the Ecuadorean embassy in London last year.
item.description: The founder of WikiLeaks said on Thursday he said he would go if his rights were “protected,” though he is not under public indictment by the United States.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Britain Opens Investigation After Officers Use Stun Gun on Race Relations Worker
item.description: The police, confusing the man with a wanted suspect, had fired a stun gun at the worker after he refused to give his name. The episode was caught on video.
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO de FREYTAS-TAMURA

item.title: South Korea Illegally Held Prostitutes Who Catered to G.I.s Decades Ago, Court Says
item.media:description: A woman named Bae, seen in a photograph from 2008, once worked as a prostitute near an American military base in South Korea. Former prostitutes say that few of their fellow citizens knew how involved their government once was in the sex trade.
item.media:credit: Jean Chung for The International Herald Tribune
item.description: The ruling is a victory for dozens of women who had pressed the government to admit that it helped create camp towns where Koreans worked in bars and brothels.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Punches, Kicks and the ‘Dangling Chair’: Detainee Tells of Torture in China
item.media:description: Xie Yang with his wife, Chen Guiqiu. Mr. Xie, a human rights lawyer who has been detained since July 2015, gave detailed accounts of torture in interviews transcribed by his attorneys.
item.description: A human rights lawyer still in custody and facing a subversion trial describes months of abuse in interview transcripts released by his attorneys.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Driver in Melbourne, Fleeing Police After Stabbing, Kills 4 Pedestrians
item.description: The police said a man with an “extensive family violence history” deliberately plowed into pedestrians in a shopping area. Children were among the dead and injured.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS and GERRY MULLANY

item.title: U.S. Airstrike Kills More Than 100 Qaeda Fighters in Syria
item.description: A flurry of airstrikes illustrates the challenges President Trump faces in carrying out the vow his inaugural address vow to combat “radical Islamic terrorism.”
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL R. GORDON and ERIC SCHMITT
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Russia Signs Deal for Syria Bases; Turkey Appears to Accept Assad
item.media:description: Gen. Ali Abdullah Ayoub of the Syrian Army visited Russia’s only aircraft carrier, the Admiral Kuznetsov, off the Syrian coast near Tartus this month.
item.media:credit: Syrian Arab News Agency, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.description: Russia showed its intent to greatly expand its military presence in Syria, and Turkey seemed to soften its opposition to President Bashar al-Assad.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND

item.title: What in the World: For a Modest Price, the Streets of Paris Can Be Yours
item.media:description: Some Paris streets still have visible cobblestone paving, but on many the stones have been buried under asphalt and are often torn up during construction. Rather than dump them, the city has started to salvage and sell the stones.
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.description: Cobblestones have lined Paris’s streets since the 12th century. When the city began selling used ones, an entrepreneur saw a chance to make unique souvenirs.
item.dc:creator: BENOÎT MORENNE

item.title: Canada Today: Political Donations, a Young Captain and Top Films
item.media:description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada with supporters in Kingston, Ontario, on Jan. 12. Mr. Trudeau took off on a nationwide tour that included town hall-style events.
item.media:credit: Adrian Wyld/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, facing two ethics investigations, skipped the World Economic Forum in favor of a cross-Canada roadshow.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: U.S. Removes Libya From List of Zones With Looser Rules for Drone Strikes
item.media:description: Barack Obama and Donald J. Trump at the presidential swearing-in ceremony at the United States Capitol on Friday. It was not clear whether Mr. Trump would keep in place civilian-protection rules established by Mr. Obama in 2013.
item.description: The Obama administration quietly removed a former extremist stronghold from a list of areas where special rules intended to prevent civilian deaths are waived.
item.dc:creator: CHARLIE SAVAGE
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Death Toll Escalates in Mistaken Bombing of Nigerian Camp
item.media:description: Onlookers waited outside the gates of a hospital in Maiduguri, Nigeria, for people wounded when an air force plane bombed a refugee camp.
item.description: Doctors Without Borders said 90 people had died in the bombing, nearly double the initial toll, and quoted residents as saying that 170 may have perished.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Yahya Jammeh Clings to Power, for Now, as 45,000 Flee Amid Gambia Standoff
item.media:description: Gambians at the Escal refugee camp in the border town of Karang, Senegal, on Friday.
item.description: Amid political paralysis in the country, the United Nations has warned of a humanitarian crisis as refugees flood across the border to Senegal.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY and JAIME YAYA BARRY

item.title: Amid Fistfights, Turkey Nears Parliamentary Approval of a New Constitution
item.media:description: Turkish lawmakers scuffled on Thursday after Aylin Nazliaka, center left, handcuffed herself to a microphone to protest proposed changes to the Constitution.
item.description: The proposal, bitterly disputed by opposition parties, would greatly expand the powers of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan if approved in a referendum.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND

item.title: The Saturday Profile: Godfather of ‘Brexit’ Takes Aim at the British Establishment
item.media:description: Arron Banks at a Leave.EU campaign party in London, on the day Britain voted to leave the European Union. He donated $11 million to the U.K. Independence Party and the unofficial Leave.EU campaign.
item.description: Arron Banks, a born disrupter and friend of Donald Trump, says his real ambition is to obliterate the Conservative Party.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER and KIMIKO de FREYTAS-TAMURA

item.title: ISIS Destroys Part of Roman Amphitheater in Palmyra, Syria
item.media:description: The Roman amphitheater, left, in Palmyra, Syria, in 2016. Satellite pictures on the right show the structure before it was damaged, above, and after.
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: Once done for ideological reasons, the destruction of heritage sites is now thought to be a matter of revenge as the militant group loses territory.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Italy Cheers as Boy Pulled From Rubble of Avalanche, Along With Others
item.media:description: The scene at the Hotel Rigopiano on Friday. The main building was torn off its foundations by an avalanche.
item.media:credit: Italian Fire and Rescue Service, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Despair turned to hope on Friday morning when at least 10 people were found alive, at the site of the isolated hotel in the Apennine Mountains that was destroyed by an avalanche.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: A Gathering of the Global Elite, Through a Woman’s Eyes
item.media:description: Iris Bohnet, a behavioral economist from Harvard, at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, where 80 percent of participants are men.
item.description: Following a behavioral economist from Harvard as she navigates the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, where 80 percent of the participants are men.
item.dc:creator: KATRIN BENNHOLD

item.title: In India, Tension Over Traditions Perilous to Animals and Humans Alike
item.media:description: Indians in Chennai protested a ban on a bull wrestling festival in Chennai on Thursday, paralyzing the streets.
item.description: Thousands of Indians are protesting a ban on a bull-wrestling tradition in Tamil Nadu, but it isn’t the only cultural tradition coming under scrutiny.
item.dc:creator: NIDA NAJAR

item.title: Martin McGuinness, an I.R.A Leader Who Later Embraced Ulster Politics, Says He’ll Retire
item.media:description: Martin McGuinness, the former first deputy minister of Northern Ireland, in London in October. His departure increases political uncertainty just as Britain plans for its departure from the European Union.
item.description: Mr. McGuinness, who resigned as deputy first minister of Northern Ireland earlier this month after an internal political dispute, announced his retirement on health grounds.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Trump Renews Vow for Jerusalem Embassy, a Gift of Uncertain Value
item.media:description: The United States Embassy in Tel Aviv, where other countries have their embassies.
item.description: Palestinians in the West Bank protested the idea, which even many hard-line Israelis are not keen to embrace, seeing it as a catalyst to more fighting.
item.dc:creator: IAN FISHER and ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Intercepted Russian Communications Part of Inquiry Into Trump Associates
item.media:description: Paul Manafort, Donald J. Trump’s former campaign chairman, at the Republican National Convention in Cleveland in July.
item.media:credit: Sam Hodgson for The New York Times
item.description: It is not clear whether the communications had anything to do with Donald J. Trump or his campaign.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT, MATTHEW ROSENBERG, ADAM GOLDMAN and MATT APUZZO
item.category: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods

item.title: Riot Police Try to Quell Continuing Violence in Brazilian Prison
item.media:description: Inmates at the Alcaçuz state penitentiary, near Natal in the state of Rio Grande do Norte, Brazil, on Thursday. The police have been unable to take control of the prison since a riot on Saturday that killed 26 inmates.
item.description: Specially equipped police officers entered a prison near the city of Natal as rival gangs battled each other with metal bars and wooden clubs in scenes reminiscent of medieval warfare.
item.dc:creator: DOM PHILLIPS

item.title: Supreme Court Justice Helping to Oversee Brazil Graft Inquiry Dies in Plane Crash
item.media:description: Teori Zavascki, a Brazilian Supreme Court justice, was killed along with at least two other people traveling on a small plane when it crashed into the Atlantic. The cause of the crash was unknown as of Thursday night.
item.description: The Supreme Court justice, Teori Zavascki, had earned a reputation as a judge prepared to curb abuses of power by influential lawmakers and business leaders.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Reporter's Notebook: A Clown and a Correspondent Join the Global Elite
item.media:description: What look like massive beach balls hanging from the ceiling are part of a project called Aerocene, led by the artist Tomás Saraceno, at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland.
item.description: Ben Hubbard, a Mideast correspondent for The Times, tags along with his wife, a storyteller who was invited to Davos as a “Cultural Leader.”
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Despite Syria Cease-Fire, U.N. Says, Aid Isn’t Reaching Besieged Areas
item.media:description: A boy carrying bread after a reported airstrike by government forces, in the Syrian town of Binnish, on the outskirts of Idlib, last week.
item.media:credit: Omar Haj Kadour/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Armed opposition groups and government forces “are routinely doing what they can, all of them it seems, to avoid us helping women, children, wounded on the other side,” an official said.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: C.I.A. Torture Detailed in Newly Disclosed Documents
item.media:description: Central Intelligence Agency headquarters in McLean, Va.
item.description: The material sheds additional light on the torture program as the future of the Senate’s classified full report on it hangs in the balance with the Obama presidency ending.
item.dc:creator: SHERI FINK, JAMES RISEN and CHARLIE SAVAGE

item.title: Reporter's Notebook: When Journalism Meets Civil Disobedience
item.media:description: At Cédric Herrou’s habitat in the foothills of the Alps outside Nice, France, where African migrants hid last September before crossing the border.
item.media:credit: Pierre Terdjman for The New York Times
item.description: I had gotten a decent man in trouble while pursuing a good story.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: 239 People Are Dead. Should Searchers Keep Looking for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370?
item.media:description: The aircraft that disappeared, photographed over Poland earlier in 2014.
item.description: A multigovernment decision to stop the search, already the longest and most expensive in aviation history, raises ethical questions.
item.dc:creator: RUSSELL GOLDMAN and MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: Theresa May Says Britain Will Lead a New Era of Free Trade
item.description: It was a jarring note from the leader of a country leaving the world’s largest free-trade group. She also urged the Davos elite to seriously address inequality.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER and STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Trilobites: Fishing for Clues to Solve Namibia’s Fairy Circle Mystery
item.media:description: A fairy circle in the NamibRand Nature Reserve in the Namib Desert.
item.description: The new study suggests that both termites and plants may be jointly responsible for forming fairy circle landscapes in Namibia.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS ST. FLEUR

item.title: Philippine Police Are Accused of Killing South Korean Businessman
item.media:description: The chief of the Philippine National Police, Ronald dela Rosa, left, with President Rodrigo Duterte in Manila on Thursday.
item.description: Officers seized Jee Ick-joo under the pretense of a drug raid last year and later extorted money from his family, the Justice Department of the Philippines said.
item.dc:creator: FELIPE VILLAMOR

item.title: Right-Wing Hoteliers in Japan Anger China With Radical Historical Views
item.media:description: Toshio Motoya, president of the APA Group, in Tokyo in 2015.
item.description: Fumiko and Toshio Motoya, founders of the APA Group and defenders of Japan’s wartime conduct, provoked threats of a boycott over a book promoted at their chain.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN SOBLE

item.title: At Least 20 Firefighters Killed in Tehran Building Collapse
item.description: One of the Iranian capital’s oldest and most prominent skyscrapers crumpled into a smoldering heap as millions watched on TV.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK and DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Sinosphere: Wife of Detained Chinese Rights Lawyer Seeks Angela Merkel’s Help
item.media:description: Protesters in Hong Kong demanding the release of the rights lawyer Jiang Tianyong in December. Mr. Jiang has been in custody since November, but the Chinese authorities have not disclosed where.
item.description: The rights lawyer Jiang Tianyong once met the German chancellor in Beijing. Now his wife is hoping that Ms. Merkel can push Beijing to disclose his whereabouts.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Avalanche in Italy Buries Hotel, Leaving up to 30 Missing
item.media:description: As many as 30 people were reported missing at the hotel.
item.media:credit: Alpine and Speleological Rescue Team, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: The disaster came after earthquakes struck the region on Wednesday, prompting officials to close schools and the subway system in Rome as a precaution.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO and GERRY MULLANY

item.title: Trudeau Hits the Road, and Crowds and Questions Follow
item.media:description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada with supporters in Kingston, Ontario, on Jan. 12. Mr. Trudeau has set off on a nationwide tour that includes town hall-style events.
item.media:credit: Adrian Wyld/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.description: With the Canadian prime minister’s image in need of some polishing, his January town-hall tour has all the earmarks of a campaign to reconnect with voters.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: 15 of the Best Journals by Our Reporters Around the World
item.media:description: A man folding blankets that are rented out to the homeless in Delhi.
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.description: The conversational and visual on-the-ground reports offered a glimpse of captivating people and places, from a “sleep mafia” in Delhi to a monastery seeking salvation in beer.
item.dc:creator: Compiled by BARBARA TIERNEY

item.title: ‘I Didn’t Want to Lose My Identity’: 16,000 Readers Reflect on Their Surnames
item.media:description: Katherine Yuk from Toronto was one of more than 16,000 readers who responded when The New York Times asked women around the world why they kept or changed their surnames when they married.
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.description: The Times asked women around the world why they had kept or changed their surnames when they married. For many, the decision carried significant weight.
item.dc:creator: HANNA INGBER

item.title: Opinion: How Not to Be Afraid
item.description: I had an apocalyptic evangelical upbringing, a father who told me too much about the Holocaust, and a grandfather who was a neo-Nazi and Jew — and I was terrified.
item.dc:creator: RACHEL MARIE STONE

item.title: Opinion: I Went to Aleppo to Study. I Left in a Convoy of Refugees.
item.media:description: A man carrying the body of his child, who was killed in an airstrike on eastern Aleppo, in 2016.
item.description: In the last weeks of the siege, we were desperate for the world to hear and help us.
item.dc:creator: LINA SHAMY
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: South Sudan Cannot Be Allowed to Collapse
item.media:description: Peacekeeping troops patrol at night in the town of Abyei, disputed territory between Sudan and South Sudan, in December.
item.media:credit: Albert Gonzalez Farran/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Current leaders on all sides must be given a graceful exit and guarantees they won’t face criminal prosecution.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW S. NATSIOS
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
